@mixedground_xyz @_axtina @KittyInuToken @AlnAndr @ensdomains @futurealisha @avsa @NBA @ReeseW @SHAQ What special powers does being a director give me here?

@mixedground_xyz @_axtina @KittyInuToken @AlnAndr @ensdomains @futurealisha @avsa @NBA @ReeseW @SHAQ What is it you want me to say here? Brantly had witherspoon.eth because the person who bought it offered it up. The same is not true for ukraine.eth; we literally have no more power here than any other ENS user.
@mixedground_xyz @_axtina @KittyInuToken @AlnAndr @ensdomains @futurealisha @avsa @NBA @ReeseW @SHAQ No, we don't - only the owner of the name can set resolvers.

@mixedground_xyz @_axtina @KittyInuToken @AlnAndr @ensdomains @futurealisha @avsa @NBA @ReeseW @SHAQ We're delighted @KittyInuToken took it into their hands to get ukraine.eth into good hands - we have no special powers when it comes to getting this done and as always we rely on the community.

@mixedground_xyz @_axtina @KittyInuToken @AlnAndr @ensdomains @futurealisha @avsa @NBA @ReeseW @SHAQ We don't have any control over what people do with their names. Past efforts have been based on either the owner reaching out to us, or one of our team reaching out to a lot of people owning prominent names and talking to them about handing them over.

@daylon_eth I think the latter would be far more corrosive to the DAO than the former. Brantly could (rightly) challenge the legitimacy of any motion to remove him based on that.

@daylon_eth People had weeks - with free redelegation - to change their delegation away from Brantly if they wished. I think it's a reasonable interpretation that anyone who remained either supports him or is indifferent.
@daylon_eth I am, to put it mildly, not a fan of changing the rules mid-vote. I do not think any decision based on excluding his vote would be legitimate.

@transmissions11 @r_ross_campbell ü§ù

@r_ross_campbell They're more or less useless as extensions, because you can't guarantee they'll run. See ERC721 for instance, where nobody uses hooks because people don't use the 'safeTransfer' methods reliably.

@r_ross_campbell But an ERC20 with 0 decimals is still a fundamentally different thing to an NFT, because it's still fungible. It makes much more sense to use a different function signature, so these two things can never be accidentally confused.

RT @ensdomains: Hey frens! Could you use a gm? We could too.

True Names Limited is hiring a General Manager to help us build the best tool‚Ä¶

@r_ross_campbell What doesn't make sense is using the same 'transfer' signature or event signatures as ERC20, when 'amount' and 'token ID' are fundamentally different things.

Hooks, 165, etc, are all improvements that became available after ERC20 was final; no sense in ignoring them.
@peter_szilagyi Just measured ours - 50mm x 35mm, side walls are ~2.2mm, but variable because it's a complex profile.

@peter_szilagyi Personally I would ignore the advice and get aluminium joists that are wide enough to accommodate two boards with a gap. That's the system we used, and it mirrors standard deck construction.
@intocryptoast @peter_szilagyi He said in another subthread that he's already obtained deck jacks.
@ChrJentzsch @BrantlyMillegan I wouldn't draw any conclusions prematurely; very few large delegates have voted yet.
@gregskril It shows I'm present and considering the options rather than just neglecting to vote.

My votes:
 - Abstain on EP6.1.
 - avsa.eth on EP6.2.
 - Yes on all four WG budgets.
 - Abstain on EP8.
It's a busy day in the ENS DAO! Go vote! https://t.co/0UwhKlsvlY

RT @futurealisha: the 4 working groups of the @ENS_DAO have funding requests proposals for Q1/Q2 2022 live now!

ENS Delegates can vote on‚Ä¶
@r_ross_campbell If you wanted to have one NFT per contract, sure, they're basically the same. But a contract with n fungible tokens is fundamentally different to one with n different NFTs.
@r_ross_campbell Augh. 721s problem was trying to follow ERC20 *at all*, not that it wasn't sufficiently close to it!
@intocryptoast @peter_szilagyi Not alu over timber - alu over plastic deck jacks. No timber involved except for the decking itself.
@intocryptoast @peter_szilagyi Aluminium will give greater strength for a given dimension, which is crucial here.
@peter_szilagyi I don't think that's very practical with most systems - deck jacks are big, and boards mostly come in random lengths, so they won't all end at the same spot.

@peter_szilagyi I am not a structural engineer, but I think you're right; it mostly matters for having enough width to drive the screws in. You need it to be wide enough to accommodate two sets of screws for where one board ends and another begins.
@AppletonDave You ain't seen nothing yet. https://t.co/ERx6AUYVBz
@peter_szilagyi It looks like our aluminium framing is 35mm high. I'll measure the thickness with calipers when I can. 30mm seems doable.
@Amxx I kind of agree - but on the other hand, charity auctions clearly work.

@peter_szilagyi Oh, that is tough. The system we used only goes down to 78mm; after 19mm for the decking and ~30mm for the joist, it doesn't leave much for a deck jack.

What sort of jacks are available to you?
@peter_szilagyi There are existing systems designed for building floating decks; I used Modas, but there are others. Using a dedicated system if you can get it removes a lot of the complexity.
@peter_szilagyi My first piece of advice would be to go to a place that sells deck supplies and ask them for a design and quote. They'll probably do it for free to sell you the materials.
@peter_szilagyi Where are you building it? Mine was a floating deck, on top of another flat surface (a waterproof membrane roof in my case).
@josephdelong https://t.co/lZTk7piCsZ
